text:
Transportation:
A milk wagon making its rounds through the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. Shown, too, is a brick encased gas tank, erected in 1874.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

View 1: 1923

View 2: A wagon loading fruit baskets, First Avenue and E. 5th Street, Manhattan

P.L. Sperr, Photographer. 1934
title: Transportation - Wagons.

text:
Transportation: A horsedrawn open barouche at Central Park (Fifth Avenue and 59th Street). The Hotel Plaza forms a background.
1938-9
Alexander Alland
This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume 'Portrait of N. Y." by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.
title: Transportation - Horse-drawn open barouche.
folder: Fifth Avenue and 59th Street, Manhattan, N.Y.

text:
Transportation:  A horse-drawn open barouche at Central Park (Fifth Avenue and 59th Street).  The Hotel Savoy-Plaza and a portion of the Squibb Building form a backdrop.

1938-9

Alexander Alland
title: Transportation - [A horse drawn open barouche in Central Park.]

text:

text:
(1)
6th Avenue, south from W. 34th Street, showing the "E1" structure and its 33rd Street Station. This was mainly patronized by shoppers to Gimbels, Sak's and Macys. The first two of these enterprises appear here occupying the 34th - 33rd and 33rd-32nd Street frontages. Note the
interstore bridge connecting these.
Views 2 and 3 show the absence of the "E1" and the station remaining. This will remain for about a month and then join the balance of this structure. Underground, at this date, the 6th Avenue Subway is under construction. At the left is Broadway, which intersects with 6th Avenue and leaves two triangular parks; the southerly of which
(Greeley Square) appears partially here.
Views 1,2 and 3:April 5, 1939.
P.L.Sperr

Sixth Avenue and Broadway, north from West 34th Street, showing
the subway construction shaft occupying the former park site
that was identified as Herald Square. This received its name from
the newspaper plant above. One-half of this site still contains
the low original building, the remainder being improved with the
towering Herald Square Building.
Broadway is on the left and 6th Avenue on the right. The
former thoroughfare is the vantage point for the photographer in
view 2 and from which he is viewing north-eastward towards the
office building at the N. E. corner of 6th Avenue and W. 35th Street.
View 1: March 29, 1939
View 2: February 18, 1939
P. L. Sperr

Sixth Avenue and Broadway, north from West 34th Street, showing

P. L. Sperr

Sixth Avenue and West 34th Street,showing the Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church,organized in 1840, and building erected in 1859.
About 1900
No record.

Battery Park: A set of 3 views in a northeastward direction towards State Street and showing there upon the low Custom House Building overshadowed by the towering Standard Oil, 60 Wall Street and the Farmers
Loan and Trust.Company Buildings.
Ju1y 11, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Battery Park - State Street (Northeast).
folder: Battery Park & State Street (Northeast)., Manhattan, NY

text:
(1)
Battery Park; A northward view of same as seen from the confluence of the North (Hudson) and East Rivers. Surrounding and over-shadowing this garden area are office structures of downtown Manhattan's
business and financial district.
July 1, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, viewing eastward, showing the Fireboat Station and the
Aquarium.
July 19, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Battery Park - [View from confluence of North (Hudson) and East Rivers.]
folder: Battery Park & [View from confluence of North (Hudson) and East Rivers.], Manhattan, NY

text:
Barclay Street, north side, west from Church st, to and including West Broadway, and showing in the foreground a portion of the new Post Office site.

March 17, 1935
folder: Barclay Street & Church Street, Manhattan, NY

text:
An aerial view of Barclay Street, south side, from No. 38,
between Church Street and West Broadway, to the Hudson River,
showing the Telephone Building in the background.
October 10, 1928.
P.L. Sperr.
